1: When treating a 30-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding, inserting the levonorgestrel-releasing intra-uterine system is the first option.
2: In adolescents, the immaturity of the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis commonly results in anovulatory oestrogen withdrawal bleedings which can be quite severe.
3: Hyperthyroidism is a cause of amenorrhoea, while hypothyroidism causes heavy menstrual bleeding.
4: Oral contraceptives for cycle control should not be used for more than three months during adolescence.
5: In patients with uterine myoma and completed families, myomectomy can still be considered.
6: In cases with dysfunctional acute heavy menstrual bleeding, tranexamic acid is the drug of choice to arrest the bleeding.
7: Once the abnormal bleeding has been stopped, the next step is to determine whether the dysfunctional bleeding is related to ovulation or anovulation.
